title.rendered: A Guide to GIC for Canadian Student Visa

content.rendered:
[vc_row type=”full_width_content” full_screen_row_position=”middle” column_margin=”default” column_direction=”default” column_direction_tablet=”default” column_direction_phone=”default” scene_position=”center” text_color=”dark” text_align=”left” row_border_radius=”none” row_border_radius_applies=”bg” overlay_strength=”0.3″ gradient_direction=”left_to_right” shape_divider_position=”bottom” bg_image_animation=”none” shape_type=””][vc_column column_padding=”no-extra-padding” column_padding_tablet=”no-extra-padding” column_padding_phone=”no-extra-padding” column_padding_position=”left-right” column_element_spacing=”30px” background_color_opacity=”1″ background_hover_color_opacity=”1″ column_shadow=”none” column_border_radius=”none” column_link_target=”_self” gradient_direction=”left_to_right” overlay_strength=”0.3″ width=”1/12″ tablet_width_inherit=”default” tablet_text_alignment=”default” phone_text_alignment=”default” bg_image_animation=”none” border_type=”simple” column_border_width=”none” column_border_style=”solid”][/vc_column][vc_column column_padding=”padding-5-percent” column_padding_tablet=”inherit” column_padding_phone=”inherit” column_padding_position=”left-right” column_element_spacing=”30px” background_color_opacity=”1″ background_hover_color_opacity=”1″ column_shadow=”none” column_border_radius=”none” column_link_target=”_self” gradient_direction=”left_to_right” overlay_strength=”0.3″ width=”7/12″ tablet_width_inherit=”default” tablet_text_alignment=”default” phone_text_alignment=”default” bg_image_animation=”none” border_type=”simple” column_border_width=”none” column_border_style=”solid”]
Share Tweet Share Pin
[vc_column_text]Prospective international students who wish to study in Canada via the Student Direct Stream will need to complete the Guaranteed Investment Certificate (GIC) process. This certificate is vital for many reasons. However, few applicants truly understand its importance and how to complete the process properly.

This guide will delve into what GIC Canada for International Students is and how it works.[/vc_column_text][vc_text_separator title=”Quick Navigation” border_width=”4″][vc_row_inner column_margin=”default” column_direction=”default” column_direction_tablet=”default” column_direction_phone=”default” text_align=”left”][vc_column_inner column_padding=”no-extra-padding” column_padding_tablet=”inherit” column_padding_phone=”inherit” column_padding_position=”all” column_element_spacing=”default” background_color_opacity=”1″ background_hover_color_opacity=”1″ column_shadow=”none” column_border_radius=”none” column_link_target=”_self” gradient_direction=”left_to_right” overlay_strength=”0.3″ width=”1/1″ tablet_width_inherit=”default” bg_image_animation=”none” border_type=”simple” column_border_width=”none” column_border_style=”solid”][vc_column_text]

  • Role of GIC in Canadian Student Visa
  • How to Open a GIC Account?
  • Is 10,000 CAD enough GIC Amount?
  • List of Reliable Banks to Open GIC Account Safely
  • GIC Refund after Refusal of Canada Study Visa
  • GIC Rejection Reasons
  • Getting Help With Your GIC
[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_custom_heading text=”What is GIC?” use_theme_fonts=”yes”][vc_column_text]The Guaranteed Investment Certificate (GIC) is essentially a deposit investment offered by Canadian banks or trust companies. This short-term liquid investment must be returned within one year and is generally offered with a guaranteed rate of return.

This GIC meaning may sound complicated at first, but it is generally straightforward. It is just like putting money in a fixed deposit (FD) or a mutual fund but for a limited time period (1 year). Also, money is deposited in certain Canadian banks that we will discuss in the following sections.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”Role of GIC in Canadian Student Visa” use_theme_fonts=”yes” el_id=”gic_canadian_student_visa”][vc_column_text]International students who intend to pursue higher education in Canada via Student Direct Stream (SDS) will need to deposit a full year’s living expenses into a Canadian bank account to be eligible for their student visa. To do that, they require a GIC Account.

This is a mandatory requirement for all international students enrolled in courses under the SDS. Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) put this requirement into place to demonstrate that you possess enough funds to cover your College or University tuition as well as living expenses during your stay in Canada.

This student GIC deposit will also be protected by the Canada Deposit Insurance Corporation (CDIC) and receive interest at the fixed rate specified during its issuance. This ensures your deposit remains safe and does not lose value over time.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”How to Open a GIC Account?” use_theme_fonts=”yes” el_id=”how_to_open_gic_account”][vc_column_text]The Government of Canada has streamlined this process to make it quick and easy for international students. However, you should generally begin the process of opening your GIC account at least one month before you intend to apply for your Canadian Student Visa. The steps for opening a GIC account are explained below.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”1. Register for Your GIC Account” font_container=”tag:h3|text_align:left” use_theme_fonts=”yes”][vc_column_text]The first step is to register for your GIC account at one of the following Canadian banks:

  • Scotiabank Canada
  • SBI Canada
  • CIBC Bank Canada
  • ICICI Bank Canada

Each of the banks mentioned above offers special services for opening GIC accounts and has made the process straightforward. You will need to start by filling out your personal details on an online application. Next, you can register for secure email services from your chosen bank.

Once this registration is complete, you should receive a password for your new email account. Your GIC application form and wire transfer details will then be sent to and accessed from this email account.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”2. Add Funds” font_container=”tag:h3|text_align:left” use_theme_fonts=”yes”][vc_column_text]Students are then required to add funds to the account. They must provide a minimum GIC amount of $10,000 CAD and GIC Canada fees for processing. These processing fees are usually between $150 CAD and $200 CAD depending on your chosen bank. Note that these funds must come from your account or a joint account in your home country.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”3. Confirmation of GIC Payment” font_container=”tag:h3|text_align:left” use_theme_fonts=”yes”][vc_column_text]Once you complete this transaction successfully, you will receive a letter (GIC certificate) from the bank confirming the amount via email. This letter must be submitted when students apply for their Canada Student Visa.

Important Note: It takes up to 7-8 days for getting your GIC certificate. In case you don’t receive it after 7-8 days then you have to contact the respective bank’s customer support. Also, make sure the address on your passport exactly matches the address you put while transferring money to the bank.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”Is 10,000 CAD enough GIC Amount?” use_theme_fonts=”yes” el_id=”GIC_Amount”][vc_column_text]$10,000 CAD is the minimum amount required for the GIC. However, students have the option of adding a more considerable sum of up to $50,000 CAD if they would like to reap the guaranteed return benefits.

Adding more than $10,000 CAD may not necessarily improve your odds of being issued a student visa. Instead, students should focus on ensuring their funds are coming from accounts under their name or a similar joint account.

Don’t forget to add additional processing fees ($150 CAD to $200 CAD) required by the bank in this amount. Sometimes students make mistake by sending only $10,000 CAD to the Canadian bank. In that case you can mail your bank your query using the secured link that they provide you during the process. Follow this useful thread to resolve this issue.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”List of Reliable Banks to Open GIC Account Safely” use_theme_fonts=”yes” el_id=”List_GIC_Banks”][vc_column_text]Prospective international students can open a GIC account safely at any of the following four GIC banks in Canada. The details for each bank are shown below.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”1. Scotiabank” font_container=”tag:h3|text_align:left” use_theme_fonts=”yes”][vc_column_text]

  • Interest Rate: 0.1 to 1%
  • Accepted Investment Amount: $10,000 CAD to $50,000 CAD
  • Processing Fees: $200 CAD
  • First Deposit to the Student Account: $2,000 CAD plus Interest
  • Monthly Deposit to the Student Account: $667 CAD plus Interest
  • Online Application Available: Yes
  • Application Processing Time: 2 to 10 days. This includes account registration time plus time to issue GIC Certificate)
  • Number of Branches in Canada: Over 1,100

Many students favor GIC Scotia bank Canada for its widespread network. It has over 4,000 ATM machines and over 1,100 branches across Canada.

You should note that Scotiabank does have a strict application process. Making minor mistakes on your application can lead to it being rejected, and result in delays in getting your GIC certificate. Scotiabank’s processing fees of $200 CAD are also higher than that of other banks.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”2. ICICI” font_container=”tag:h3|text_align:left” use_theme_fonts=”yes”][vc_column_text]

  • Interest Rate: 1%
  • Accepted Investment Amount: $10,000 CAD
  • Processing Fees: $150 CAD
  • First Deposit to the Student Account: $2,000 CAD
  • Monthly Deposit to the Student Account: $667 CAD plus Interest
  • Online Application Available: Yes
  • Application Processing Time: 2 to 5 days. This includes account registration and wire transfer time plus time to issue GIC Certificate)
  • Number of Branches in Canada: 7

ICICI GIC is favored by international students who may wish to apply for an ICICI Canada Debit Card from their home country, provided that ICICI has branches there. This bank has only seven branches in Canada, meaning that students may need to travel a fair distance to visit this bank if they are studying outside the Greater Toronto Area (GTA).[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”3. SBI” font_container=”tag:h3|text_align:left” use_theme_fonts=”yes”][vc_column_text]

  • Interest Rate: 1.05%
  • Accepted Investment Amount: $10,000 CAD
  • Processing Fees: $150 CAD
  • First Deposit to the Student Account: $2,000 CAD
  • Monthly Deposit to the Student Account: $667 CAD plus Interest
  • Online Application Available: Yes
  • Application Processing Time: 4 to 10 days. This includes account registration and wire transfer time plus time to issue GIC Certificate)
  • Number of Branches in Canada: 7

SBI Canada GIC is a less popular option for international students. This branch has many of the drawbacks associated with ICICI, such as a limited number of branches in Canada. SBI also has a reputation for offering limited customer service compared to other banks in the country.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”4. CIBC” font_container=”tag:h3|text_align:left” use_theme_fonts=”yes”][vc_column_text]

  • Interest Rate: 1.25%
  • Accepted Investment Amount: $10,000 CAD to $20,000 CAD
  • Processing Fees: $150 CAD
  • First Deposit to the Student Account: $2,000 to $12,000 CAD depending on investment amount
  • Monthly Deposit to the Student Account: $1,000 CAD plus Interest
  • Online Application Available: Yes
  • Application Processing Time: 2 to 4 days. This includes account registration and wire transfer time plus time to issue GIC Certificate)
  • Number of Branches in Canada: Over 1,200

CIBC is a popular option for international students who intend to study under the SDS programs. This bank has fast processing times, low processing fees, and a higher acceptance rate than Scotiabank.

They also have a large number of bank branches scattered across Canada, making it easy for international students to access their services in the country.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”GIC Refund after Refusal of Canada Study Visa” use_theme_fonts=”yes” el_id=”GIC_refund”][vc_column_text]If your study permit is declined or cancelled the Bank will refund the balance available in your GIC account after minus the applicable processing fees. For security reasons, most of the banks refund the GIC Amount to the account where funds were initially received from.

Very Important Note: Make sure that you transfer money to GIC Account from your personal bank account only. In many cases the immigration agents make GIC payments with their account. Thus, on study visa refusal they get the GIC amount refunded to their account instead of student’s account.[/vc_column_text][vc_video link=”https://youtu.be/LURwU9rf554?t=39″][vc_custom_heading text=”GIC Rejection Reasons” use_theme_fonts=”yes” css=”.vc_custom_1646768377804{margin-top: 50px !important;}” el_id=”GIC_rejection_reasons”][vc_column_text]The most common GIC rejection reasons are mentioned below:

  1. Mismatched details: Your passport is the most relevant document for the bank. During the payment, make sure all the details like name, address, etc. are the same as in the passport.
  2. Skipping Processing Fees: Remember that you have to send the minimum GIC amount plus processing fees.
  3. A Mistake by Bank: In many cases, banks accidentally fill the wrong address which is not consistent with your passport. Both the address in the GIC account and the address in your passport should match.
[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text=”Getting Help With Your GIC Certificate and Student Visa” use_theme_fonts=”yes” css=”.vc_custom_1646768388596{margin-top: 50px !important;}” el_id=”help”][vc_column_text]Navigating the GIC certificate application process can be challenging for international students who would prefer to focus on their upcoming studies. A poorly-optimized GIC application may be outright refused, resulting in delays in getting your certificate.

Prospective international students can reach out to COLOSSUS’s experts for assistance with their GIC application and student visa. Our team of immigration consultants is familiar with the GIC application process and the vital role it plays in student visa applications.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column column_padding=”padding-4-percent” column_padding_tablet=”no-extra-padding” column_padding_phone=”no-extra-padding” column_padding_position=”left-right” column_element_spacing=”30px” background_color_opacity=”1″ background_hover_color_opacity=”1″ column_shadow=”none” column_border_radius=”none” column_link_target=”_self” gradient_direction=”left_to_right” overlay_strength=”0.3″ width=”4/12″ tablet_width_inherit=”default” tablet_text_alignment=”default” phone_text_alignment=”default” bg_image_animation=”none” border_type=”simple” column_border_width=”none” column_border_style=”solid”][vc_raw_html]JTNDZGl2JTIwY2xhc3MlM0QlMjJtbC1mb3JtLWVtYmVkJTIyJTBBJTIwJTIwZGF0YS1hY2NvdW50JTNEJTIyMzgxOTE0NiUzQWIyYzNtMHIxYzklMjIlMEElMjAlMjBkYXRhLWZvcm0lM0QlMjI1NDY1NDI2JTNBdTJ4Mms4JTIyJTNFJTBBJTNDJTJGZGl2JTNF[/vc_raw_html][vc_custom_heading text=”Trending Stories” font_container=”tag:h3|font_size:26|text_align:left|color:%230a0a0a” use_theme_fonts=”yes” css=”.vc_custom_1644853159092{margin-top: 40px !important;margin-bottom: 30px !important;}”][recent_posts style=”list_featured_first_row” columns=”1″ category=”all” order=”DESC” orderby=”date” image_loading=”default” blog_remove_post_date=”true” blog_remove_post_author=”true” blog_remove_post_comment_number=”true” blog_remove_post_nectar_love=”true” posts_per_page=”5″ post_offset=”1″][/vc_column][/vc_row]
